instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Hello, i have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with green light on charger but no power.

All rails are present till <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>. It doesnt show any sign of corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.
If present. check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL>.

Be aware, this board should restart 2 times before booting, when charger is connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message: Yes, i get pulses from  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>,   <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  when triggering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Then check if each bg coil pulse at same time.
Also check pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Coils pulsing:

L7320
L7310
L7630
L7430
L7520
L7130

Coils not pulsing:

L3095
L7701

Pin 7 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is pulsing but 3 is not (0v).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message: Check for pulse at pins 5 & 6 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Then pin 3 MUST pulse too.
If not, change <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message: Pin 3 is pulsing, my bad, i think the probes didnt reach well.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Power cycles every 5 seconds, or just 1, or 2 pulses when connect charger?

Try starting in SMC bypass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Power cycles every 3 seconds indefinitely.

No power on with SMC Bypass.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message: Can you catch any pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message: Yes, theres a pulse every 3 sec.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean/remove J6100, if needed.
Try known good working BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR> was giving me 380 ohms where it should be 15. I replaced it for a 15 one.

There was a trace missing from <RESISTOR>R6128</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> and i soldered a wire, it has continuity now. 

I clenaed J6100 and it looks pretty, should i still replace it?

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is recognized by the programmer. I reprogrammed the BIOS with one from another  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.

Still not turning on.

I noticed wheni try to turn on SMC bypass the fan spins for a sec then stops, then again and again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b green light no power
threads.message:
You can remove J6100, if do not use it to flash <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.

We have tested 3437 BIOS files posted on the forum for sure.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_vUaRGjasq1rYvM6pfckGOvb-ljLB7FT/view?usp=sharing[/URL]
Just in case...
